p: The genus Eryngium L., which belongs to the subfamily Saniculoideae of the Apiaceae family, is represented by 230â€“250 species widespread in Central Asia, America, and Central and Southeast Europe [ 1]. Among them, there are some species such as E. campestre, E. maritimum, E. foetidum, and E. creticum that have been used in the traditional medicines worldwide [ 2]. The pharmacological activities of Eryngium species depend mainly on the presence of triterpenoid saponins, flavonoids, phenolic acids, coumarin derivatives, acetylenes, and the essential oils [ 3, 4].
